Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Modified Blumgart Mattress Suture in Pancreaticojejunostomy

Background: This randomised controlled trial (RCT) aimed to evaluate whether the modified Blumgart mattress suture technique during pancreaticojejunostomy (PJ) reduces the incidence of clinically relevant postoperative pancreatic fistula (POPF) after pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD).

Methods: Conducted at Wakayama Medical University Hospital, 224 patients scheduled for PD between June 2013 and May 2017 were randomised to either the interrupted suture group or the modified Blumgart mattress suture group. Eligible participants were those scheduled for PD, excluding those with severe comorbidities or requiring additional organ resection. The primary outcome was the incidence of grade B/C POPF within 90 days, defined by the International Study Group on Pancreatic Fistula criteria. Randomisation was computerised with a permuted block size of 4, stratified by pancreatic texture. Blinding was not applied. The trial was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01898780).

Results: A total of 103 patients in the interrupted suture group and 107 in the modified Blumgart group were analysed by intention-to-treat. Grade B/C POPF occurred in 7 patients (6.8%) in the interrupted group and 11 (10.3%) in the modified Blumgart group (P = 0.367). Mortality within 90 days was 0 in both groups. No significant differences in postoperative complications were observed.

Interpretation: The modified Blumgart mattress suture did not significantly reduce the incidence of clinically relevant POPF compared to the interrupted suture. The study was funded by institutional sources.
